reviewText: Although the older Classic FIRMS are the best that was ever made (as well as the Original Fitprimes), I really loved this cardio workout from the BSS series. For some reason I really always like any workout lead by Nancy because her cuing is always good and she has a relaxing voice even if the workout is challanging. Although this workout isn't advanced, you can certainly make it advanced by using heavier dumbells or a taller step. I love that this one is a bit longer and I never felt bored once since there are many segments. I wish the music was a little bit better, but the music was still good and upbeat.:)There are no abs worked in this video, but still a good solid little cardio add on or on its own, still good.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This is a very cardio workout from the Firm.The Firm always pleases me.I am very pleased again with Super Cardio Sculpt.This is a very fun heart pumping workout.It used light weights about 3 pounds and the firm fanny lifter.They use the top 6 inch section and the 14 inch platform.It is a mix of low impact floor aerobics,great cardio step aerobis that are really fun and pretty easy to follow and also fanny lifter climbs using the dumbells.You might not be used to the footwork at first but when you get used to you`ll love this workout.Beginners might have a hard time with the fanny lifter climbs,they just have to use the 8 inch platform at first and don`t use the weights at first.I love this tape know,I really got a good sweat on.The Firm always comes out with a good workout.
summary: Very Good Cardio workout with weights
Title: N/A

reviewText: Yes, I realize I'm reviewing a 6 year old workout video, but I love the FIRM "oldies", on VHS, which I buy at used book stores. This workout is fully enjoyable, adaptable to beginners, and a good calorie burner for all levels. The footwork is a bit more tricky than in other FIRM videos (causing me to fall off the step once--result not typical), but never to the point of being "dancy", and each section seems easier than the one before. I thought they could have done a slow demo of the "tri-star" move rather than the V-step, but overall, anyone can catch on easily after doing this video 1-2 times. The sculpting is pretty much integrated into the cardio sections, except for 1 relatively short segment on the fanny lifter. Just the right length--a quickie compared to some FIRM videos--and the cueing is the best of probably ANY exercise video I own--no kidding--she does a great job & helps you navigate the footwork in the beginning.
Title: N/A

reviewText: I really enjoyed this cardio workout.  With some of their past cardio workouts, "too long" and others "too short", the length at 40 minutes is "just right".  Equipment needed are 3 pound dumbbells to increase the intensity of the workout (beginners are recommended to use none) and the Fanny Lifter.  A step of some sort could be substituted, but one short part of the workout will need to be modified.  I often use the Transfirmer in lieu of the Fanny Lifter and even though it was 3 times the width of the Fanny Lifter, it wasn't an issue for that portion of the workout.While there was variety to the steps, it wasn't hopelessly complicated, as I've whined about in reviews of The Firm's other cardio workouts, with Express Cardio with Lisa Kay most notably infuriating.I thought Nancy Tucker did a good job of cuing the video and was motivating and encouraging without being annoying.I'm an intermediate exerciser of many years and I worked up a sweat with the first use, but wasn't gasping for breath or struggling in any way, even through the fast paced sections.If you've never done a Firm Cardio workout, this may be a good one to start with, as the learning curve won't be as bad as Fat Blast Cardio, Express Cardio and even Cardio Sculpt Blaster (the last of which I've come to love, but took quite a while to master the footwork).I look forward to using this workout regularly.  The time flew by!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I'm a "Firm Believer" and own several of their DVD's and Videos. I must say in general, the Firm Tapes are not quite as tough as when the first company owned THE FIRM.This tape was fun and Nancy Tucker is great at explaining the moves. It took 2 sessions to get the footwork down, which is fine.  I would have liked to use more weights and get a more total workout. I'm very disappointed there was no ab work.  This being called Super Cardio Sculpt - I was apprehensive that it was going to be super hard, but it's not. You'll sweat, but it's really not tough.Also FIRM and other workout companies need to up their quality and put up a menu! I accidentally turned it off because of a phone call, and then had to start it again and Fast Forward till I finally found my spot on the tape. Come'on... if you're manufacturing tapes for a living, they should be more sophisticated and user friendly.The BEST firm tapes were from the beginning days with Susan Harris... where are you!?  And Janet Jones tapes. My gosh! Your entire body burns from them. People comment at how amazing my body looks and I know its from these tapes. Dramatic results, but not so sure about the new ones yet.From the new series, I like the Fanny Lifter, and the new Firm Box, which I bought and love the results with both of those.  Some of the new tapes seem to be specific to a body part or goal.
Title: N/A

reviewText: In this 40 minute workout you will find a variety of cardio, step aerobics, low impact with options to add small hops or jumps, 4 limb aerobics using light weights, and a tall box section also using light weights.  You will need the Firm's famous Fanny Lifter for this one, fully assembled for the tall box section, and using the short piece for the step aerobics. If you do not have the Fanny Lifter, a step stool and any step box would work. Light weights (3lbs are recommended)are also used, although the option of using no weights is also there.Nancy Tucker leads this workout along with 4 fellow Firm Master Instructors including Libby who shows beginner modifications which in this video are no weights and low impact moves.  They are all wearing turquoise colored tops and black bottoms, going with the matching color scheme that is common in the newer Firm videos.  Nancy is a pleasant instructor, she offers helpful tips throughout and seems to be having a good time.The choreography is easy to follow and Nancy does a decent job of cuing.  The step moves are basic, basic steps, knee lifts, repeaters, over the tops, straddles and others.  The other aerobic combinations are simple moves, nothing too tricky plus you have options to decrease the intensity should the need arise, Nancy offers polite reminders of this.This workout is better suited for beginner/intermediate levels, advanced will find it too easy.  But it's a fun workout, and I recommended for those who like a cardio variety and simple moves to get the heartrate up.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This workout was released in the early 2000s in a series called "Add Ons" that was meant to compliment The Firm's Body Sculpting Series (BSS) 1 & 2. There are 6 total and range from 30-45 minutes. Super Cardio Sculpt is longest in duration of the 6 workouts. I have had this DVD now for 10 yrs and only after today, did I finally enjoy it.Back when I first purchased these in a bundle with the BSS2 workouts & Fanny Lifter, this was one of 2 workouts that I avoided like the plague. I found Nancy in this workout to be boring and dry and I could not for the life of me make it more than 20 minutes before I punted the workout from my player. Fast Forward to today and I am loving how fresh this feels. I've spent too much money over the past decade on literally HUNDREDS of DVDs trying to find the in-home workout(s) that not only (A)fits my needs but (B) also offers some fun and variety without being "Balls to the Wall" and "Puke in the Bucket" Intense. I want something that I can grow with from beginner to Low-Advanced without pain, injury, or stress; especially important when one comes back to fitness after injury, illness, or pregrancy. Basically, something that works with me regardless of what stage of life I am in. It's always The Firm and Leslie Sansone that I come back to with open arms. The set is bright, the music is generic, and it looks clean and inviting. The Set is not crammed and the instructors are in great shape and feature different body types although all are slim. Some would see the instructors as Stepford-ish, but I find them familiar and comfortable as I've used these workouts off and on for years. The choreography is moderate. It will be more challenging for beginners unless you have Step Aerobics experience- Gin Miller's Everybody Steps has a majority of the patterns but a slower pace for instructional purposes (it does however use a traditional Club Step). With this workout you get the benefit of both floor aerobics and step aerobics with each segment lasting 5-6 minutes with the warm up being around 8-9. Each segment has new choreography so the exerciser has variety to keep motivation and energy high. You will use a light set of dumbbells for two segments focusing on upper body, mostly biceps however triceps, shoulders, and upper back are worked in the first of the two segments. There is very little breakdown for the choreography so be prepared to either rewind the workout to learn the footwork or learn it over a period of time while making a fumble here and there. Even mistakes burn calories! There is one set of Tall Box Climbs which is during the second sculpting series and just before the cool down (cool down begins at minute 38:38). Cool fown is your last aerobics segment and uses the step. It's lower intensity and isn't a traditional cool down with respect to other popular instructors and brands on the market. If you're not careful, you can easy keep your heart up!I knocked 1 star off for the "sculpting". Since this is labeled Super Cardio Sculpt, I was hoping to have not only more sculpting work but also work with 2-3 sets of dumbbells. It's a very minor gripe but they suggest using 3s which IMO, only adds to the cardio exertion, not really benefiting the muscle building side of things. However with time or depending on your current fitness level, you can always increase the weights to an amount that suites you best as long as proper form is maintained. If you want an all sculpting workout, one that uses the step, and is under 35 minutes, look at Body Sculpt Blaster, also from this series and it's also led by Nancy.NOTE: For individuals looking to purchase this workout you will need the Fanny Lifter. As of 2012, The Fanny Lifter has been renamed "The TransFirmer". This is very important to take notice of because if you wish to collect workouts to use with this equipment you must purchase workouts labeled to use with the Fanny Lifter (purple and blue box). "The TransFirmer" was originally released for the BSS 4 Workouts (you can use the BSS 3 workouts too) in the mid 2000s and it is a long, rectangle box, colors blue and green. Any workout labled before 2012 as a TransFirmer Workout is for the Original TransFirmer, not the renamed Fanny Lifter!!!
Title: N/A
